abstract.text: 3D SceneKit content drawn as a flattened sprite.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: objects to incorporate 3D SceneKit content into a SpriteKit-based game. When SpriteKit renders the node, the SceneKit scene is animated and rendered first. Then this rendered image is composited into the SpriteKit scene. Use the
property to specify the SceneKit scene to be rendered.

abstract.text: Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
3D SceneKit content drawn as a flattened sprite.
A Boolean value that determines whether Scene Kit automatically adds lights to a scene.
Searches the Scene Kit scene for objects corresponding to a point in the rendered image.
Tells you when to initialize a 3D node that has been unarchived.
Initializes a new 3D node.
A Boolean value that determines whether the scene is playing.
A Boolean value that determines whether Scene Kit restarts the scene time after all animations in the scene have played.
Creates and initializes a new 3D node.
The Scene Kit node from which the scene’s contents are viewed when rendered.
Projects a point from the 3D world coordinate system of the SceneKit scene to the 2D viewport coordinate system of the SpriteKit node.
The current scene time.
The SceneKit scene to render.
Unprojects a point from the SpriteKit node’s 2D viewport coordinate system to the 3D world coordinate system of the SceneKit scene.
The size of the image rendered by the node.
A source of various particle effects.
A graphical element that draws text.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
A mathematical shape that can be stroked or filled.
An image or solid color.
A two-dimensional array of images.
A graphical element that plays video content.
Draw SceneKit content in a SpriteKit scene by using a 3D node.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Displaying 3D Content in a SpriteKit Scene

abstract.text: Structure your nodes for maximum performance.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
